TITLE: Elon Musk must close Twitter deal by end of this week or face trial
SUMMARY: The clock is ticking for Elon Musk to complete his deal to buy Twitter.

TITLE: EU formally adopts law requiring Apple to support USB-C chargers
SUMMARY: A landmark law requiring Apple and other electronics makers to adopt USB-C as a universal charging standard in the European Union has cleared its final procedural hurdle, after EU member states voted to approve the legislation on Monday.

TITLE: Apple raises prices for music and TV streaming services
SUMMARY: Apple on Monday raised the price of its music and video streaming services, in the latest example of streaming products getting more expensive in recent months.

TITLE: YouTube rolls out new features and an updated look
SUMMARY: YouTube is rolling out what it calls a "small makeover" with a handful of new features and design changes intended to make watching videos on the platform a better experience.

TITLE: FTC seeks to clamp down on alcohol delivery service Drizly and its CEO after data breach
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Commission is seeking tough new restrictions against Drizly, the alcoholic beverage delivery platform, after what US regulators allege were repeated security failures that compromised the data of 2.5 million people.

TITLE: WhatsApp suffers major outage
SUMMARY: WhatsApp suffered a serious outage on Tuesday, preventing users across the globe from sending or receiving messages on the platform.

TITLE: For widows on Facebook, updating relationship status is complicated
SUMMARY: After Rebecca Kasten Higgins lost her husband in a car accident a few days before their 20th anniversary in 2018, she kept her relationship status as "married" on Facebook for three years. Then she started dating someone.

TITLE: Amazon to let customers pay with Venmo at checkout
SUMMARY: Amazon is rolling out a new option for customers to pay with Venmo.

TITLE: First on CNN: LinkedIn knows there are fake accounts on its site. Now it wants to help users spot them
SUMMARY: In recent months, bots have been top of mind for many who track the social media industry, thanks to Elon Musk's attempt to use the prevalence of fake and spam accounts to get out of his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter. But bots aren't just a challenge for Twitter.

TITLE: Amazon workers in California withdraw petition for union vote after defeat in New York
SUMMARY: Six months after the grassroots Amazon Labor Union scored a historic victory by becoming the first to unionize one of the tech giant's US facilities, it now appears to be grappling with setbacks and delays.

TITLE: Google's core business is slowing down amid recession fears
SUMMARY: Google may be the giant in the digital advertising world, but even it is not immune to the impact that the economic downturn and recession fears are having on the online ad market.

TITLE: New space cargo ship makes first flight
SUMMARY: Orbital Sciences Corp. sent up its first entry into the space freight business Wednesday, launching a new unmanned cargo carrier to the Intl. Space Station.

TITLE: Gamers gear up for 'Grand Theft Auto V'
SUMMARY: Gamers on Tuesday get their hands on "Grand Theft Auto V," the latest in the controversial franchise.
HLN's Jennifer Westhoven describes a new breathalyzer app for your smartphone.

TITLE: Study: Mobile Web use has doubled since 2009
SUMMARY: According to a new study, 21% of phone owners use their devices as their primary way of accessing the Internet.

TITLE: Inventions inspired by trauma and tragedy
SUMMARY: Necessity, so the saying goes, is the mother of all invention. But as history often shows adversity is often the catalyst for creativity, inspiring inventors to life-saving feats of ingenuity.
The iPhone 5S comes with a capacitive home button that can read your fingerprint. Some wonder if its safe from hackers.

TITLE: How secure is your iPhone 5S fingerprint?
SUMMARY: Given privacy concerns, the idea of handing over one's fingerprints to Apple via its new iPhone 5S has some people nervous.

TITLE: Apparently This Matters: Doomsday bunker
SUMMARY: CNN humor columnist Jarrett Bellini looks at an amazing doomsday bunker for sale in Las Vegas.

TITLE: Zuckerberg: I want to meet a new person daily
SUMMARY: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has vowed to speak to one non-Facebook employee a day during 2013

TITLE: The laser light that could cut cyclist deaths
SUMMARY: The Blaze laser bike light could dramatically reduce cyclist fatalities around the world.

TITLE: Rocket frog takes a flying leap
SUMMARY: Frogggsss in spaaaccceee!

TITLE: Feds unveil new app to help catch pedophiles
SUMMARY: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement has unveiled an iPhone app called Operation Predator that asks the public for help in gathering information on suspected child sexual predators, including those who are fugitives.

TITLE: The cassette tape turns 50
SUMMARY: The cassette should have died. Instead, it's turning 50 in an atmosphere of celebration.

SUMMARY: CNN's Heather Kelly spent a few minutes with new newly launched iPhones Tuesday. Here's what she thought.

SUMMARY: Google may be the giant in the digital advertising world, but even it is not immune to the impact that the economic downturn and recession fears are having on the online ad market.

SUMMARY: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton sued Google on Thursday, alleging the tech giant had violated the state's biometric privacy law by "indiscriminately" collecting voiceprints and facial recognition data from users and non-users of the company's products without their consent.

TITLE: Elon Musk must close Twitter deal by end of this week or face trial
SUMMARY: The clock is ticking for Elon Musk to complete his deal to buy Twitter.

TITLE: Online creators hit with IP and copyright lawsuits
SUMMARY: For decades, co-called "copycat" court cases boiled down to 'you stole my idea.' Now, they are testing the rights of fans, artists and rivals to re-interpret others intellectual property on new-media platforms.

TITLE: Facebook and TikTok are approving ads with 'blatant' misinformation about voting in midterms, researchers say
SUMMARY: Facebook and TikTok failed to block advertisements with "blatant" misinformation about when and how to vote in the US midterms, as well as about the integrity of the voting process, according to a new report from human rights watchdog Global Witness and the Cybersecurity for Democracy Team (C4D) at New York University.

TITLE: Apple's industrial design chief to depart company three years after Jony Ive
SUMMARY: Apple's industrial design chief who most recently oversaw the design of products including the iPhone, Apple Watch and Mac computers is leaving the company.

TITLE: Twitter stock falls after report says Biden admin weighing security review of Musk ventures
SUMMARY: Shares of Twitter dropped as much as 8% in pre-market trading Friday as investors braced for some last-minute uncertainty around Elon Musk's $44 billion deal to buy the company.

TITLE: These artists found out their work was used to train AI. Now they're furious
SUMMARY: In just months, millions of people have flocked to text-to-image AI systems and they are already being used to create experimental films, magazine covers and images to illustrate news stories. An image generated with an AI system called Midjourney recently won an art competition at the Colorado State Fair, and caused an uproar among artists.

TITLE: Snap stock falls nearly 25% after revenue hit by shrinking advertiser budgets
SUMMARY: Snap's bad year continues.

TITLE: Korean auto giant Hyundai investigating child labor in its U.S. supply chain
SUMMARY: Hyundai Motor Co, Korea's top automaker, is investigating child labor violations in its U.S. supply chain and plans to "sever ties" with Hyundai suppliers in Alabama found to have relied on underage workers, the company's global chief operating officer Jose Munoz told Reuters on Wednesday.

TITLE: Behind the NSA's mysterious coded tweet
SUMMARY: When the National Security Agency sent a tweet Monday filled with garbled nonwords like "tpfccdlfdtte," the Internet was confused, and intrigued.

TITLE: Meet Netflix's stealthy new logo
SUMMARY: Netflix has a new logo, but you're forgiven if you didn't notice.

TITLE: How might your boss know when you've slept?
SUMMARY: Will wearables make us more productive? More satisfied? Or just give bosses another way to spy on workers?

TITLE: Why test-tube meat may be the future of food
SUMMARY: A new breed of entrepreneurs are applying tech-startup principles to the challenges of global food production.

TITLE: Apparently This Matters: Airplane armrests
SUMMARY: CNN humor columnist Jarrett Bellini looks at a new design for airplane armrests.

TITLE: 'Club sandwich' may hold life on Jupiter moon
SUMMARY: Jupiter's moon Ganymede may have several ice and water layers inside, and life could have arisen there.

TITLE: The African app company that trumped Apple
SUMMARY: Tech firm Oju Africa has tackled the lack of racially diverse emoticons by introducing its own set of Afro icons.

SUMMARY: The wearable technology movement is in full effect, and exercise-based activity trackers lead the way. Now, it's becoming child's play.

TITLE: The spaceship reinvented for new frontiers
SUMMARY: Radical redesign is 100% reusable, offering more frequent, cheaper and deeper flights into space.

TITLE: Computers that know what we want
SUMMARY: The growing field of "predictive tech" is producing digital tools smart enough to fetch information for you -- before you realize you even need it.
Selfies and biometrics may replace the use of passwords on your phones. CNN's Samuel Burke explains from the Las Vegas 2015 Consumer Electronics Show.

TITLE: Africa's mobile money makes its way to Europe
SUMMARY: Snapchat may be the latest application to offer a mobile payment feature, but the idea that made it possible was spawned more than 7 years ago in Africa.

TITLE: Brain hat helps paralyzed make music
SUMMARY: A musician met a patient with locked in syndrome 11 years ago. Now he's created a way for the people suffering from paralysis to make music with their eyes.

TITLE: Deciphering the conductor's code
SUMMARY: Andris Nelsons, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, uses his gestures as code for the large orchestra.
Smart gadgets and appliances at the Consumer Electronics Show may save people money, but they may cause security problems. CNN's Samuel Burke reports.

TITLE: The 11 most amazing crowdsourcing apps
SUMMARY: From avoiding traffic jams to finding the best public toilet in town, crowdsourcing apps are showing that many smartphones make for light work.

TITLE: They tried to break the Internet in 2014
SUMMARY: No one thing actually "broke" the Internet in 2014, but here are 10 of the memes and hashtags that tried.

TITLE: What you really Googled in 2014
SUMMARY: In 2013, people just wanted to know how to twerk. This year, people wanted to know if they had Ebola, according to Google's Year in Search.

TITLE: Wind farms of the future could be underwater
SUMMARY: The United Kingdom may seem an unlikely candidate to lead a renewable energy revolution; it doesn't have much sun for solar power, it doesn't have much space for wind power and it doesn't have giant coursing rivers for hydro.

TITLE: NASA's plan for a floating city above Venus
SUMMARY: Imagine a blimp city floating 30 miles above the scorching surface of Venus: a home for astronauts in one of the solar system's most inhospitable planets.

TITLE: VProud: Meet the 'troll-slayer'
SUMMARY: VProud: Has Karen Cahn created the first 'troll-proof' website for women?

TITLE: The new CNN Digital
SUMMARY: Editor In Chief Meredith Artley welcomes you to the new mobile and desktop sites for CNN.

TITLE: 'Digital nose' on a chip sniffs out diseases
SUMMARY: A British startup called Owlstone has created a microchip that can detect chemical molecules in the air with great accuracy.

TITLE: After the comet, Mercury is next for ESA
SUMMARY: After landing a probe on an icy comet, the European Space Agency (ESA) is now heading to scorching-hot Mercury with its BepiColombo spacecraft.

TITLE: Going up! Space elevator may ride on diamonds
SUMMARY: Want to ride an elevator into space? An old idea, reinvented with nanotechnology and a 'diamond necklace'.

TITLE: How to bake the perfect bike
SUMMARY: Want to make a super-light, super-fast bike? Stitch it from carbon fibers and bake to perfection.

TITLE: Filming the sea's neon light show
SUMMARY: Some sea creatures emit a neon glow known as bioluminescence. This remarkable camera lets it be seen on film like never before.

TITLE: Why NASA wants humans on Mars by 2035
SUMMARY: NASA's chief scientist wants to land humans on Mars by 2035.

TITLE: Mobile World Congress: The future
SUMMARY: Mobile World Congress isn't just about cell phones -- this year's event showcased the technology of tomorrow.

TITLE: The 'memristor': A new era for electronics?
SUMMARY: A new type of electrical component called "memristor" could mean the end of electronics as we know it and the beginning of a new era called "ionics".

TITLE: Earthquake app may one day warn you tremors are coming
SUMMARY: What would you do with a 40-second warning that an earthquake is coming? Scientists are working on an app to warn a quake is coming and give people time to move.

TITLE: How the Challenger disaster changed NASA
SUMMARY: The Challenger disaster grounded NASA's space shuttle program for nearly three years. "But look at how we flew after," says Robert Cabana, former NASA astronaut and director of the Kennedy Space Center.

TITLE: Beyond Pistorius: rise of the 'cyberathletes'
SUMMARY: A revolution in prosthetics is transforming lives and sporting competition.

TITLE: Fitbit captures moment of heartbreak
SUMMARY: Wearables have become a popular way of tracking our daily workout, eating habits and sleep cycles. But one man inadvertently captured the moment his heart broke.

TITLE: Hoverboards that actually hover? They're here
SUMMARY: Real, flying hoverboards are here. Will they change the way we get around?

TITLE: World's first cyborg wants to hack your body
SUMMARY: Neil Harbisson is the world's first legally recognized cyborg. He has an antenna in his skull that gives him the ability to see color.

TITLE: 10 great quotes from Steve Jobs
SUMMARY: Many Steve Jobs quotes come from his 2005 speech at Stanford, when he told graduates, "Your time is limited, so don't waste it living someone else's life."

TITLE: The 5 faces of Steve Jobs
SUMMARY: An Einstein, a harsh taskmaster, selfish, evasive and cruel. Alex Gibney's CNN film "Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine" shows Jobs however you want to see him.

TITLE: In-wheel motors could be the future of electric cars
SUMMARY: The Lightyear 0, a new solar-powered car, uses in-wheel electric motors, which were first introduced over 100 years ago and might be staging a comeback.

TITLE: Firefighters see through smoke with new mask
SUMMARY: Firefighters have relied on thermal cameras to locate victims, but a new device projects thermal image into firefighters' masks.

TITLE: Making Star Wars-style 'vaporators' real
SUMMARY: In Star Wars, Luke's family obtained water in the desert by farming it from the air with fictional "vaporators." But could they work in the real world?
Millions of Americans lack access to affordable, healthy food. Food Oasis LA, an app created by people living in Los Angeles's food deserts, aims to tackle that issue with a click of a button.

TITLE: Which type of tailgater are you?
SUMMARY: When it comes to tailgating, some sports fans are just there for party. But for others, it's all about the food, gadgets or showing off the freshest team apparel.

TITLE: DOJ plans to disrupt global spam network after hacker's arrest
SUMMARY: The US Department of Justice announced an "extensive effort to disrupt and dismantle" a network of thousands of compromised computers under the control of an alleged cybercriminal, a statement released Monday said.

TITLE: 'Orange goo' is used in armor for soldiers and football players
SUMMARY: An unusual gel is being used to protect soldiers and might radically reduce the number of head trauma injuries in American football.

TITLE: Hotel room photos could stop sex traffickers
SUMMARY: TraffickCam is an app that could help police locate hotel rooms used for sex trafficking.
CNN's Jonathan Mann finds out how Google captured images from inside an active volcano.

TITLE: Dubai to launch driverless flying taxi service
SUMMARY: Dubai will get a fleet of flying taxis this summer -- electric, driverless drones.
NASA used a high-powered radar signal to locate India's missing Chandrayaan-1 unmanned lunar orbiter.

Hellosmile is a pediatric health care startup that serves 50,000 kids in New York City's low-income neighborhoods. With concerns over Medicaid funding under Trump, hellosmile's future remains uncertain.
Boeing finalized designs for the 777-9X, which has folding wings and is expected to be the world's largest twin-engine jet when it begins service in 2020.

TITLE: Girl asks Google for job and gets a response
SUMMARY: After seeing pictures of Google offices decked out with bean bags and slides, 7-year-old Chloe Bridgewater decided Google was the company for her.

TITLE: How NASA set out to solve a 'space poop' problem
SUMMARY: While hurtling through the cosmos, the last thing an astronaut wants to worry about is what to do when nature calls -- and competition's winner has a solution.

TITLE: Timeline: Elon Musk's plan for humanity
SUMMARY: Elon Musk has already changed our lives multiple times over. So what does he have planned for us next?
A french businessman is suing Uber claiming a glitch in the app caused his wife to suspect him of cheating and led to their divorce.
Olympic champion Australia and fellow women's rugby superpower New Zealand were unable to reach the final of the Sydney Sevens, where Canada beat the US.
The London Science Museum has opened an exhibit featuring hundreds of years of robots, including one created around the year 1560.

SUMMARY: The iPhone will support USB-C charging in the European Union to comply with a new ruling that mandates electronic devices have a common charging standard, an Apple executive said Tuesday night.

TITLE: WhatsApp suffers major outage
SUMMARY: WhatsApp suffered a serious outage on Tuesday, preventing users across the globe from sending or receiving messages on the platform.

TITLE: EU formally adopts law requiring Apple to support USB-C chargers
SUMMARY: A landmark law requiring Apple and other electronics makers to adopt USB-C as a universal charging standard in the European Union has cleared its final procedural hurdle, after EU member states voted to approve the legislation on Monday.

TITLE: FTC seeks to clamp down on alcohol delivery service Drizly and its CEO after data breach
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Commission is seeking tough new restrictions against Drizly, the alcoholic beverage delivery platform, after what US regulators allege were repeated security failures that compromised the data of 2.5 million people.

TITLE: YouTube rolls out new features and an updated look
SUMMARY: YouTube is rolling out what it calls a "small makeover" with a handful of new features and design changes intended to make watching videos on the platform a better experience.

TITLE: Apple raises prices for music and TV streaming services
SUMMARY: Apple on Monday raised the price of its music and video streaming services, in the latest example of streaming products getting more expensive in recent months.

TITLE: Texas sues Google over alleged 'indiscriminate' biometric data collection
SUMMARY: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton sued Google on Thursday, alleging the tech giant had violated the state's biometric privacy law by "indiscriminately" collecting voiceprints and facial recognition data from users and non-users of the company's products without their consent.

TITLE: Elon Musk must close Twitter deal by end of this week or face trial
SUMMARY: The clock is ticking for Elon Musk to complete his deal to buy Twitter.

TITLE: Online creators hit with IP and copyright lawsuits
SUMMARY: For decades, co-called "copycat" court cases boiled down to 'you stole my idea.' Now, they are testing the rights of fans, artists and rivals to re-interpret others intellectual property on new-media platforms.

TITLE: Facebook and TikTok are approving ads with 'blatant' misinformation about voting in midterms, researchers say
SUMMARY: Facebook and TikTok failed to block advertisements with "blatant" misinformation about when and how to vote in the US midterms, as well as about the integrity of the voting process, according to a new report from human rights watchdog Global Witness and the Cybersecurity for Democracy Team (C4D) at New York University.

TITLE: Apple's industrial design chief to depart company three years after Jony Ive
SUMMARY: Apple's industrial design chief who most recently oversaw the design of products including the iPhone, Apple Watch and Mac computers is leaving the company.

TITLE: Twitter stock falls after report says Biden admin weighing security review of Musk ventures
SUMMARY: Shares of Twitter dropped as much as 8% in pre-market trading Friday as investors braced for some last-minute uncertainty around Elon Musk's $44 billion deal to buy the company.

TITLE: Elon Musk visiting Twitter headquarters this week ahead of expected deal closing
SUMMARY: Elon Musk plans to visit Twitter's San Francisco office this week ahead of the expected close of his deal to buy the company, Twitter Chief Marketing Officer Leslie Berland told staff in an email Wednesday.

TITLE: Meta posts second-ever quarterly revenue decline and hints at cost cutting efforts
SUMMARY: Meta on Wednesday posted the second quarterly revenue decline in its history since going public and warned that it is making "significant changes" aimed at cutting costs ahead of 2023, as it confronts an economic downturn that is hitting its core online advertising business.

TITLE: Meta's stock falls 17% as its quarterly profit is cut in half
SUMMARY: Meta on Wednesday posted the second quarterly revenue decline in its history since going public and warned that it is making "significant changes" aimed at cutting costs ahead of 2023, as it confronts an economic downturn that is hitting its core online advertising business.

TITLE: Ford takes $2.7 billion hit as it drops efforts to develop full self-driving cars
SUMMARY: Ford is essentially pulling the plug on an effort to develop its first full self-driving car, and it's going to cost the automaker $2.7 billion to walk away.

TITLE: Samsung names billionaire scion Jay Y. Lee as chairman
SUMMARY: Samsung has appointed Jay Y. Lee, its longtime de facto leader, as executive chairman.

TITLE: Is the iPhone 14 recession proof? Apple earnings may provide a hint
SUMMARY: Apple is about to offer its first hints about iPhone 14 sales after weeks of rumors that demand for its latest smartphone lineup could be weaker than initially expected.

TITLE: Elon Musk tells advertisers he doesn't want Twitter to become 'free-for-all hellscape'
SUMMARY: Elon Musk attempted to reassure Twitter's advertisers about the future of the platform in an open letter Thursday, a day before his $44 billion takeover of the company is expected to be completed.

TITLE: Apple earnings may offer a hint about the iPhone 14's success
SUMMARY: Apple is about to offer its first hints about iPhone 14 sales after weeks of rumors that demand for its latest smartphone lineup could be weaker than initially expected.

TITLE: Apple is weathering the economic downturn better than fellow tech giants
SUMMARY: Apple beat Wall Street analysts' sales and income expectations for the quarter ended in September, despite an otherwise bruising earnings season for tech companies and worries that demand for the newest iPhones might have been weaker-than-expected.

TITLE: Amazon stock falls nearly 20% on light holiday quarter sales forecast
SUMMARY: Amazon stock fell nearly 20% in after-hours trading Thursday after the company forecast its holiday quarter sales would be lighter than analysts had expected.

TITLE: Amazon stock falls 14% on light holiday quarter sales forecast
SUMMARY: Amazon stock fell some 14% in after-hours trading Thursday after the company forecast its holiday quarter sales would be lighter than analysts had expected.

TITLE: Elon Musk has taken control of Twitter and fired its top executives
SUMMARY: Elon Musk has completed his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter, a source familiar with the deal told CNN Thursday.

TITLE: Elon Musk now owns Twitter. Here's what he could change
SUMMARY: After spending months attempting to get out of his deal to buy Twitter, Elon Musk officially owns the hugely influential platform. Now the question is: What will he actually do with it?

TITLE: Elon Musk's bumpy road to owning Twitter: A timeline
SUMMARY: A board seat accepted and then rejected. A stunning $44 billion takeover offer with uncertain financing. And a surprise early morning tweet putting the deal on hold, temporarily.

TITLE: Twitter confirms completion of Elon Musk's $44 billion acquisition deal
SUMMARY: Elon Musk has completed his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter, the company confirmed in a securities filing Friday, putting the world's richest man in charge of one of the world's most influential social media platforms.

TITLE: Elon Musk will have to pay three fired Twitter executives nearly $200 million
SUMMARY: The three top Twitter executives whom Elon Musk fired Thursday will walk out the door with about $187 million of Musk's money.

TITLE: Anxious Twitter users find few alternatives to platform after Musk deal closes
SUMMARY: In the hours after Elon Musk completed his purchase of Twitter late Thursday, many avid users began voicing their uncertainty about the future of the platform and whether they want to remain on it. But with few obvious alternatives, Twitter users may be left with nowhere else to go.

TITLE: GM pauses advertising on Twitter after Elon Musk takeover
SUMMARY: General Motors is pausing its advertising on Twitter now that the social media platform is owned by Tesla CEO Elon Musk, the company said in a statement Friday.

TITLE: Analysis: Elon Musk owning Twitter should give everyone pause
SUMMARY: In late May, something unusual happened at Twitter. Shareholders voted to approve two proposals to change how the company operates â€” and did so against Twitter's recommendations.

TITLE: Facebook became Meta one year ago. Its metaverse dream feels as far away as ever
SUMMARY: Even by Facebook's standards, 2021 was a rough year.

TITLE: US curbs on China's microchip industry could throttle Xi Jinping's tech ambitions
SUMMARY: Chinese leader Xi Jinping's push to "win the battle" in core technologies and bolster China's position as a tech superpower could be severely undermined by Washington's unprecedented steps to limit the sale of advanced chips and chip-making equipment to the country, analysts say.

TITLE: Elon Musk disbands Twitter's board, cementing control over company
SUMMARY: Twitter's board of directors was dissolved on Thursday following Elon Musk's takeover of the company, according to a securities filing on Monday.

TITLE: Instagram goes down for some users
SUMMARY: Thousands of Instagram users reported issues with accessing the platform on Monday morning.

TITLE: Want a blue check mark on Twitter? It may soon cost you $19.99 a month
SUMMARY: Twitter is considering offering verified accounts to users who are willing to pay $19.99 a month for a subscription service, and it may take away the coveted blue check marks of existing users if they don't start paying for the product within 90 days, according to internal Twitter documents viewed by CNN.

TITLE: Senate Democrat wants national security investigation of Saudi Arabia's role in Elon Musk-Twitter deal
SUMMARY: Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy is calling on the federal government to investigate national security concerns raised by Saudi Arabia's role in Elon Musk's takeover of Twitter.

TITLE: Uber revenue jumps 72% on strong demand for rides
SUMMARY: If a recession is looming, you wouldn't know it from looking at Uber's business.

TITLE: Workers flee China's biggest iPhone factory over Covid outbreak
SUMMARY: Foxconn, one of Apple's largest suppliers, is wrestling with massive disruptions at its iPhone assembly factory in China, once again highlighting the impact of the country's stringent zero-Covid policy on international business.

TITLE: After Elon Musk's wild weekend on Twitter, will advertisers stick with it?
SUMMARY: Hours before news broke on Thursday that he had completed his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter, Elon Musk wrote an open letter to advertisers stressing that he doesn't want the platform to become a "free-for-all hellscape."

TITLE: After Elon Musk's antics on Twitter, advertisers may think twice for now
SUMMARY: Hours before news broke on Thursday that he had completed his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter, Elon Musk wrote an open letter to advertisers stressing that he doesn't want the platform to become a "free-for-all hellscape."

TITLE: Musk suggests charging $8 a month for Twitter verification after criticism for $19.99 plan
SUMMARY: After facing criticism for his plan to charge Twitter users $19.99 a month to get or keep a verified account, Elon Musk has a counteroffer: maybe $8?

TITLE: Musk says Twitter will charge $8 a month for account verification after criticism for $19.99 plan
SUMMARY: After facing criticism for his plan to charge Twitter users $19.99 a month to get or keep a verified account, Elon Musk has a counteroffer.

TITLE: Twitter founder Jack Dorsey to remain invested in the company under Elon Musk
SUMMARY: Twitter co-founder and former CEO Jack Dorsey stepped down from the company's board earlier this year, but he's staying involved with the social platform following its takeover by Elon Musk.

TITLE: Elon Musk hints that Donald Trump will not be back on Twitter before the midterms
SUMMARY: Elon Musk indicated on Wednesday that the Twitter account of former President Donald Trump will not be restored ahead of the US midterm elections next week, answering one of the biggest unknowns following his takeover of the social media company.

TITLE: FCC commissioner calls for TikTok ban
SUMMARY: The US government should ban TikTok rather than come to a national security agreement with the social media app that might allow it to continue operating in the United States, according to Brendan Carr, a commissioner at the Federal Communications Commission.

TITLE: Twitter's C-suite clears out as Musk cements power over the company
SUMMARY: On October 27, the same day Elon Musk completed his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter, the company's chief customer officer, Sarah Personette, tweeted that she "had a great discussion" with the social network's new owner.

TITLE: TikTok makes clear European data can be accessed by China-based employees
SUMMARY: TikTok updated its privacy policies for European users on Tuesday, adding explicit disclosures that personal data from the app may be viewed by employees in China.

TITLE: Amazon will pause corporate hiring for months
SUMMARY: Amazon is pressing pause on corporate hiring and expects to keep the policy in place for months, in the latest sign that even the biggest tech companies are rethinking staffing in an uncertain economic climate.

TITLE: Lyft to lay off 13% of staff
SUMMARY: Lyft on Thursday said it will lay off 13% of its staff, or nearly 700 employees, as it rethinks staffing amid rising inflation and fears of a looming recession.

TITLE: Elon Musk wants Twitter users to pay to be verified. It could create a new set of headaches for the company
SUMMARY: In 2009, after Twitter was sued by then-St. Louis Cardinals manager Tony La Russa for being impersonated on the platform, the young company introduced a new feature: a blue and white check mark.

TITLE: Elon Musk's Twitter informs staff layoffs are set to begin
SUMMARY: Elon Musk will begin laying off Twitter employees on Friday morning, according to a memo sent to staff. The email sent Thursday evening notified employees that they will receive a notice by 12 pm ET Friday that informs them of their employment status.

TITLE: General Mills and Audi pause Twitter ads after Musk takeover
SUMMARY: Elon Musk's advertising problem is getting worse.

TITLE: Elon Musk's Twitter begins laying off employees across the company
SUMMARY: Elon Musk's Twitter has begun laying off employees across the company, after an internal memo on Thursday warned that cuts would be coming.

TITLE: Elon Musk said Twitter has seen a 'massive drop in revenue' as more brands pause ads
SUMMARY: Elon Musk said Friday that Twitter has seen a "massive drop in revenue," as a growing number of advertisers pause spending on the platform in the wake of his $44 billion acquisition.

TITLE: Elon Musk's Twitter lays off employees across the company
SUMMARY: Twitter on Friday laid off employees in departments across the company, in a severe round of cost cutting that could potentially upend how one of the world's most influential platforms operates one week after it was acquired by billionaire Elon Musk.

TITLE: With Twitter in chaos, Mastodon is on fire
SUMMARY: In the week since Elon Musk took over Twitter, the number of people signing up for a small social network called Mastodon has surged.

TITLE: Twitter delays $8 'blue check' verification plan until after the midterms
SUMMARY: Twitter is delaying the rollout of account verifications for its paid Twitter Blue subscription plan until after the midterm elections, a source with knowledge of the decision confirmed to CNN.
